newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-OPINION - Canberra Closeup: Where Howard dares not tread.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-OPINION - Canberra Closeup: Where Howard dares not tread.

text.p: By Jim Middleton (ABC TV Political Correspondent)
Employment Minister Amanda Vanstone has made it something of a habit to step where John Howard would not dare -- and where he wishes she wouldn't.
This week was no different.
With unemployment figures out yesterday, jobs were always going to be central to the week's political debate.
Labor jumped on the prime minister's refusal to set a target for job growth -- an issue he dodged before the election and had been ducking ever since.
Kim Beazley set the tone in question time on Monday by asking Howard: "Why will you set a target for inflation and for cutting small business red tape, but not one for unemployment?"
The prime minister was determined to do everything but answer the question.
However, Beazley was able to take advantage of recently reinstituted supplementary questions to put Howard on the spot again.
The prime minister jutted out his chin and remained defiant.
"I am not going to commit this government to a quantitative target," he declared.
All very well, but it does not sit well with a leader who has talked of the need to elevate political credibility and honesty.
There is a very practical reason for his obfuscation and and it appears on page 2-24 of budget paper No. 1.
Treasury's official forecast for employment growth this financial year is a meagre 1.5 percent -- not enough to bring about any fall in unemployment.
Even though Howard declared jobs -- especially jobs for the young -- was one of the key issues of the election campaign.
So he must have been particularly pleased when Senator Vanstone volunteered to the 7.30 Report's Kerry O'Brien on Wednesday that the government would lose office if unemployment did not fall.
O'Brien: "Unemployment will fall?"
Vanstone: "As I've said to you, we won't get re-elected if it doesn't."
Labor frontbencher Martin Ferguson declared the Employment Minister had done what Howard would not -- set a jobs target.
Kim Beazley saw the opening and chased Howard through it.
The prime minister would not take the bait.
But it may provide a little discomfort for the government in the campaign for the by-election no-one wants -- the upcoming poll in the outer western Sydney seat of Lindsay.
It was caused by the failure of Liberal MP Jackie Kelly to quit the air force -- an office of profit under the crown -- before nominations closed.

One key Liberal strategist suggests -- only half jokingly -- that it would have been better if the Court of Disputed Returns had handed the seas to the defeated member, former Labor minister Ross Free.
"At least we could have gone on about democracy being the loser rather than facing the distraction of yet another campaign with an uncertain outcome," he says.
Lindsay had been a safe Labor seat -- Kelly gained a swing of more than 11 percent and now has a cushion of 1.6 percent.
Free instigated the action which saw Kelly disqualified.
Some members of his party wish he hadn't. A by-election soon after a tough budget should be a lay-down misere for Labor.
But with the budget generally well received, some Labor MPs fear the poll will become a referendum on Beazley instead.
Already there are mutterings about the way deputy Gareth Evans' confessional apprach to the job is diminishing Beazley's effectiveness.
As one Labor figure put it: "I wish Gareth would just throw the economics textbook away and realise it's a political, not an intellectual contest."

Labor frontbenchers acknowledge the ALP has had a tougher time finding its feet in opposition than the coalition has had in adjusting to government. Especially since the budget -- and Senator Vanstone notwithstanding.
They acknowledge that this week the government had a genuine question time strategy, counter-attacking Labor over rorting of the research and development syndicate scheme for example.
By the same token, they admit the Labor operation has to become more disciplined to be an effective opposition.
The decision not to keep pressing the government over the rising price of health insurance was identified as one clear mistake.
The Carr government is on the nose in New South Wales State -- about-faces over motorway tolls and on hospital funding are not likely to be forgotten in Sydney's west.
So Lindsay could well be the reverse of the usual by-election.
"Send a message to Bob Carr", was suggested half-seriously as a possible Liberal slogan by one canny old time campaigner.
It's a message which could give the Liberals more hope in Lindsay than they could have expected a month ago, a message to give Kim Beazley more than a slight case of the shivers.
(Views are those of the author, not those of Reuters)
-- Reuters Canberra Bureau 61-6 273-2730
